importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, establishing himself as a top young talent.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, highlighting his influence in media and public chess education.
The 2025 US Chess Championship held a moment of silence for Naroditsky, showing the ongoing impact of his legacy in competitive chess.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: From 2007 to 2025, Naroditsky’s career spanned elite competition, education, and digital outreach, making him a pivotal figure in modern chess development.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at age 29.
He earned the title of grandmaster before high school graduation and won major youth championships early in life.
Naroditsky was a prolific educator and commentator, contributing to Chess Life magazine and becoming a chess columnist for The New York Times.
He built a massive online presence with nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers, livestreaming games and teaching accessible chess strategies.
The Charlotte Chess Center and International Chess Federation publicly mourned his passing, recognizing his contributions to the chess community.
The 2025 US Chess Championship honored him with a moment of silence, demonstrating his lasting influence on competitive chess.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29. Born in the San Francisco Bay Area, he earned the grandmaster title before high school and won major youth championships, including the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007. He later earned a bachelor’s degree in history from Stanford University and became a prominent chess educator, contributing to Chess Life magazine and writing for The New York Times as a columnist. Through his YouTube and Twitch platforms, he built a massive online following—nearly half a million subscribers on YouTube and 340,000 on Twitch—livestreaming games and teaching accessible chess strategies. The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, and the International Chess Federation publicly mourned his death, and the 2025 US Chess Championship honored him with a moment of silence, underscoring his profound impact on both competitive and educational chess communities.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
